OldTestament.name: Genesis
OldTestament.intro: Genesis introduces God as Creator and tells the beginnings of the world, humanity, and Israel. It recounts stories of Adam and Eve, Noah, Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and Joseph. The book emphasizes God’s promises, human failure, and His plan of redemption.

OldTestament.name: Exodus
OldTestament.intro: Exodus narrates Israel’s deliverance from slavery in Egypt under Moses’ leadership. God reveals His power through plagues, the Red Sea crossing, and provision in the wilderness. It highlights covenant at Sinai, God’s presence, and the building of the tabernacle.

OldTestament.name: Leviticus
OldTestament.intro: Leviticus provides laws for Israel’s worship and daily life, emphasizing holiness. It details sacrifices, priestly duties, and festivals that teach God’s holiness and mercy. The book shows how sinful people can live in fellowship with a holy God.

OldTestament.name: Numbers
OldTestament.intro: Numbers recounts Israel’s wilderness journey marked by rebellion, testing, and God’s faithfulness. Despite their disobedience, God provides guidance and prepares them for the Promised Land. The book teaches trust in God’s promises despite hardships.

OldTestament.name: Deuteronomy
OldTestament.intro: Deuteronomy records Moses’ final speeches before Israel enters the Promised Land. It reviews God’s laws, covenant faithfulness, and calls the people to wholehearted obedience. The book stresses love for God, remembering His works, and passing faith to future generations.

OldTestament.name: Joshua
OldTestament.intro: Joshua tells of Israel’s conquest and settlement of the Promised Land. God fulfills His promises by granting victory through obedience and faith. The book highlights courage, covenant loyalty, and the inheritance of God’s people.

OldTestament.name: Judges
OldTestament.intro: Judges describes a cycle of sin, oppression, repentance, and deliverance in Israel. God raises leaders called judges to rescue His people despite widespread disobedience. It highlights human weakness and God’s mercy in times of chaos.

OldTestament.name: Ruth
OldTestament.intro: Ruth tells the story of loyalty, kindness, and God’s providence through ordinary lives. Ruth’s devotion to Naomi leads her to Boaz and into the family of David. The book reveals God’s care and His plan unfolding through faithful love.

OldTestament.name: 1 Samuel
OldTestament.intro: 1 Samuel describes Israel’s transition from judges to monarchy under Saul and David. It emphasizes obedience to God over outward appearance or human strength. David rises as a man after God’s heart, despite struggles and trials.

OldTestament.name: 2 Samuel
OldTestament.intro: 2 Samuel focuses on David’s reign, showing his victories, sins, and God’s covenant promise. The narrative shows both blessings of godly leadership and consequences of failure. God’s plan of redemption continues through David’s family line.

OldTestament.name: 1 Kings
OldTestament.intro: 1 Kings recounts Solomon’s wisdom, temple building, and decline into idolatry. After his reign, the kingdom splits into northern Israel and southern Judah. Prophets emerge to call people back to covenant faithfulness.

OldTestament.name: 2 Kings
OldTestament.intro: 2 Kings continues the history of Israel and Judah, marked by rebellion and judgment. Prophets like Elisha call kings to repent, but most ignore God’s word. The book ends with exile, showing consequences of persistent unfaithfulness.

OldTestament.name: 1 Chronicles
OldTestament.intro: 1 Chronicles retells Israel’s history with focus on David’s reign and temple preparation. Genealogies emphasize God’s covenant promises through His chosen line. The book highlights worship, prayer, and God’s presence with His people.

OldTestament.name: 2 Chronicles
OldTestament.intro: 2 Chronicles emphasizes the kings of Judah, temple worship, and prophetic warnings. It shows blessings for obedience and consequences of idolatry and sin. The book closes with exile but ends with hope of restoration.

OldTestament.name: Ezra
OldTestament.intro: Ezra recounts the return of exiles and the rebuilding of the temple in Jerusalem. God restores His people and renews their worship through His law. Ezra calls the nation to repentance and faithfulness to God’s covenant.

OldTestament.name: Nehemiah
OldTestament.intro: Nehemiah tells how Jerusalem’s walls were rebuilt despite opposition. Through prayer, courage, and perseverance, God’s people restored their city and covenant. The book underscores faith, leadership, and renewal in community life.

OldTestament.name: Esther
OldTestament.intro: Esther describes God’s deliverance of His people through Esther’s courage. Though God’s name is not mentioned, His providence is clear in every event. The story reveals God’s hidden hand and the power of faithful action.

OldTestament.name: Job
OldTestament.intro: Job wrestles with suffering, faith, and the mystery of God’s purposes. Through loss and pain, Job questions but ultimately trusts God’s wisdom. The book highlights God’s sovereignty and human dependence on Him.

OldTestament.name: Psalms
OldTestament.intro: Psalms is a collection of songs and prayers expressing every emotion to God. It includes praise, lament, thanksgiving, and trust in God’s faithfulness. These poems guide worship and strengthen faith across generations.

OldTestament.name: Proverbs
OldTestament.intro: Proverbs offers wisdom for living faithfully in God’s world. It contrasts righteousness and wickedness, wisdom and folly, diligence and laziness. Rooted in the fear of the Lord, it guides practical daily life.

OldTestament.name: Ecclesiastes
OldTestament.intro: Ecclesiastes reflects on life’s fleeting nature and the emptiness of worldly pursuits. The Teacher explores meaning, toil, and mortality, finding vanity apart from God. True fulfillment is found in fearing God and keeping His commands.

OldTestament.name: Song of Songs
OldTestament.intro: Song of Songs is a poetic celebration of love and marital intimacy. It honors passion, commitment, and covenant joy as God’s design. The book also reflects God’s faithful love for His people.

OldTestament.name: Isaiah
OldTestament.intro: Isaiah proclaims judgment and hope, revealing God’s holiness and salvation. He announces the coming Messiah, the suffering servant, and God’s future kingdom. The book blends warning with promises of restoration and eternal peace.

OldTestament.name: Jeremiah
OldTestament.intro: Jeremiah warns of judgment on Judah for its unfaithfulness. Despite rejection and hardship, he delivers God’s call to repentance. The book also promises a new covenant and hope beyond exile.

OldTestament.name: Lamentations
OldTestament.intro: Lamentations is a poetic mourning over Jerusalem’s destruction. It expresses grief, confession, and cries for mercy amid suffering. Yet it also affirms God’s steadfast love and faithfulness that never fail.

OldTestament.name: Ezekiel
OldTestament.intro: Ezekiel shares visions of God’s glory, judgment, and restoration. He calls Israel to repent while portraying God’s holiness and presence. The book ends with hope of renewal and a future temple.

OldTestament.name: Daniel
OldTestament.intro: Daniel tells of faithfulness in exile and God’s sovereignty over kingdoms. Through visions and miracles, God shows His plan for the future. The book emphasizes trust in God’s rule despite opposition.

OldTestament.name: Hosea
OldTestament.intro: Hosea uses marriage as a picture of God’s love for His unfaithful people. Despite Israel’s idolatry, God calls them back with compassion. The book highlights both judgment and redeeming love.

OldTestament.name: Joel
OldTestament.intro: Joel describes a devastating locust plague as a picture of God’s judgment. He calls the people to repentance and promises restoration. The book points to God’s Spirit being poured out in the last days.

OldTestament.name: Amos
OldTestament.intro: Amos warns Israel of coming judgment for injustice and idolatry. He calls for true worship expressed in righteousness and justice. The book ends with hope of restoration under David’s line.

OldTestament.name: Obadiah
OldTestament.intro: Obadiah delivers judgment against Edom for its pride and cruelty. God’s justice is certain against all who oppose His people. The book ends with the promise of God’s kingdom triumphing.

OldTestament.name: Jonah
OldTestament.intro: Jonah tells of a reluctant prophet sent to Nineveh. Despite running away, Jonah witnesses God’s mercy toward repentant sinners. The story highlights God’s compassion for all nations.

OldTestament.name: Micah
OldTestament.intro: Micah proclaims judgment for injustice and idolatry in Israel and Judah. He also promises the coming ruler from Bethlehem and God’s restoration. The book emphasizes justice, mercy, and walking humbly with God.

OldTestament.name: Nahum
OldTestament.intro: Nahum announces God’s judgment on Nineveh for its cruelty and pride. The book portrays God as both just and a refuge for His people. It assures that evil will not prevail forever.

OldTestament.name: Habakkuk
OldTestament.intro: Habakkuk questions God about injustice and suffering in the world. God answers with a call to live by faith and trust His timing. The book ends with a prayer of confidence in God’s salvation.

OldTestament.name: Zephaniah
OldTestament.intro: Zephaniah warns of the coming day of the Lord against sin and rebellion. He calls for repentance and promises future restoration for the faithful. The book highlights God’s judgment and redeeming love.

OldTestament.name: Haggai
OldTestament.intro: Haggai encourages the people to rebuild the temple after exile. He reminds them of God’s presence and promises greater glory to come. The book calls for renewed priorities and obedience.

OldTestament.name: Zechariah
OldTestament.intro: Zechariah offers visions of encouragement and calls for repentance. He points to God’s coming King, the Messiah, who will bring peace. The book emphasizes hope, restoration, and God’s future kingdom.

OldTestament.name: Malachi
OldTestament.intro: Malachi rebukes Israel for neglecting worship and covenant faithfulness. He calls them to return to God with sincere devotion. The book promises a coming messenger and the day of the Lord.

NewTestament.name: Matthew
NewTestament.intro: Matthew presents Jesus as the promised Messiah and King. It emphasizes His teachings, miracles, and fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy. The book ends with the Great Commission to make disciples of all nations.

NewTestament.name: Mark
NewTestament.intro: Mark portrays Jesus as the powerful Son of God and servant. It moves quickly through His miracles, teachings, and sacrifice. The gospel highlights discipleship and the call to follow Christ.

NewTestament.name: Luke
NewTestament.intro: Luke emphasizes Jesus’ compassion and mission to all people. It contains parables, healings, and stories showing God’s mercy to the marginalized. The gospel highlights salvation as God’s gift through Christ.

NewTestament.name: John
NewTestament.intro: John presents Jesus as the eternal Word and Son of God. Through signs and teachings, it shows that believing in Him brings life. The gospel emphasizes love, truth, and the Spirit’s work.

NewTestament.name: Acts
NewTestament.intro: Acts narrates the birth and growth of the early Church through the work of the Holy Spirit. It follows Peter and Paul as they spread the gospel across the Roman Empire. The book emphasizes courage, faith, and God’s guidance in mission.

NewTestament.name: Romans
NewTestament.intro: Romans presents a systematic explanation of salvation through faith in Christ. Paul teaches about sin, grace, justification, and living by the Spirit. The letter shows God’s plan for Jews and Gentiles alike.

NewTestament.name: 1 Corinthians
NewTestament.intro: 1 Corinthians addresses divisions, immorality, and misuse of spiritual gifts in the church. Paul teaches unity, love, and proper worship. The book emphasizes practical Christian living and resurrection hope.

NewTestament.name: 2 Corinthians
NewTestament.intro: 2 Corinthians defends Paul’s apostleship and ministry. He encourages generosity, reconciliation, and endurance in suffering. The letter emphasizes God’s comfort and power in weakness.

NewTestament.name: Galatians
NewTestament.intro: Galatians teaches salvation by grace through faith, not by the law. Paul defends Christian freedom and calls believers to live by the Spirit. The book emphasizes identity in Christ and unity in the gospel.

NewTestament.name: Ephesians
NewTestament.intro: Ephesians explains the Church as Christ’s body and God’s eternal plan of salvation. Paul teaches unity, love, spiritual growth, and armor of God for spiritual battles.

NewTestament.name: Philippians
NewTestament.intro: Philippians is a letter of joy and encouragement. Paul thanks the believers for support, exhorts humility, and urges steadfast faith. The book emphasizes rejoicing in the Lord in all circumstances.

NewTestament.name: Colossians
NewTestament.intro: Colossians teaches the supremacy of Christ over all creation and false teachings. Paul encourages believers to live in Christ and bear fruit through love and good works.

NewTestament.name: 1 Thessalonians
NewTestament.intro: 1 Thessalonians encourages believers to stand firm in faith and hope. Paul instructs on holy living, love, and readiness for Christ’s return. The book emphasizes perseverance and comfort in trials.

NewTestament.name: 2 Thessalonians
NewTestament.intro: 2 Thessalonians corrects misunderstandings about the Day of the Lord. Paul calls for steadfastness, work ethic, and encouragement, highlighting God’s justice and faithfulness.

NewTestament.name: 1 Timothy
NewTestament.intro: 1 Timothy gives guidance for church leadership, sound teaching, and godly living. Paul instructs Timothy on prayer, doctrine, and character needed for ministry.

NewTestament.name: 2 Timothy
NewTestament.intro: 2 Timothy is Paul’s final letter, urging faithfulness and endurance. He encourages Timothy to continue preaching the gospel boldly despite persecution.

NewTestament.name: Titus
NewTestament.intro: Titus provides guidance on church organization, teaching sound doctrine, and encouraging good works among believers.

NewTestament.name: Philemon
NewTestament.intro: Philemon is a personal letter appealing for forgiveness and reconciliation between a slave and his master. It reflects Christian love, mercy, and practical application of faith.

NewTestament.name: Hebrews
NewTestament.intro: Hebrews presents Christ as the perfect high priest and fulfillment of the Old Testament. It encourages perseverance, faith, and understanding God’s promises.

NewTestament.name: James
NewTestament.intro: James emphasizes practical faith expressed in works, patience, and wisdom. He calls believers to live righteous, faithful, and humble lives.

NewTestament.name: 1 Peter
NewTestament.intro: 1 Peter encourages believers facing persecution. It teaches hope, holiness, and submission to God while enduring suffering.

NewTestament.name: 2 Peter
NewTestament.intro: 2 Peter warns against false teachers and reminds believers of Christ’s return. It encourages growth in faith and knowledge of God’s promises.

NewTestament.name: 1 John
NewTestament.intro: 1 John stresses love, obedience, and assurance of salvation. It contrasts truth and falsehood, emphasizing God’s love in Christ.

NewTestament.name: 2 John
NewTestament.intro: 2 John warns against deceivers and encourages walking in truth and love. It emphasizes faithfulness to God’s commandments.

NewTestament.name: 3 John
NewTestament.intro: 3 John commends hospitality and faithfulness among believers. It highlights support for those spreading the gospel and warns against pride and opposition.

NewTestament.name: Jude
NewTestament.intro: Jude urges believers to contend for the faith and warns against false teachers. It emphasizes God’s judgment and the need for perseverance in truth.

NewTestament.name: Revelation
NewTestament.intro: Revelation unveils visions of Christ’s return, final judgment, and the establishment of God’s eternal kingdom. It encourages faithfulness, hope, and perseverance amid trials.
